column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make a Bracelet on a Cardboard Loom
#Text=You want to make a bracelet , but you do n’t know how .
#Text=You do n’t have a loom and you do n’t have the money to buy one .
#Text=That 's okay , you can just make a loom out of cardboard .
#Text=This is a fun activity that is easy to learn .
#Text=You can turn the bracelets you make into friendship bracelets , regular bracelets , or any other type of bracelet .
#Text=Here are some simple steps to help you out .
#Text=Happy bracelet making !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Organizing The Thread
#Text=Pick out your colors .
#Text=You can have as many as 7 and as little as 1 color .
#Text=The more colors you have , the more exciting your bracelet will be !
#Text=Measure your threads so you can tie them .
#Text=Take one thread color and wrap it around your wrist or ankle about 7-8 times .
#Text=Your bracelet wo n't need to be this long , but it is better to have it longer than not have enough to finish !
#Text=After you cut this thread , use it as a template for all your other colors and cut them the same length , too .
#Text=You will need 7 total threads so you can have three , fold in half , then add one and tie , or have four ties and then cut one out .
#Text=Combine all your threads and fold them all in half . ( This helps tie it off later ) On the end with a loop , tie a knot about half an inch 1/4 to 1/2 an inch .
#Text=Now you are ready to make the loom .
#Text=Making The Cardboard Loom
#Text=Find a piece of cardboard .
#Text=You can use anything from a cereal box to a packing box , but you need some sort of cardboard that will be stable enough for you to pull things through it .
#Text=Cut the cardboard into the right shape .
#Text=Take a cup or bowl and trace it on your cardboard and cut it out .
#Text=To make it your loom , you will need to measure 8 cuts all around the circle all about 1/2 inch deep .
#Text=They should be about 1 inch apart from each other but that will depend on how big your circle is .
#Text=To finish it off , poke a small hole in the center and you are done with your loom .
#Text=Making the Bracelet
#Text=To set it up , you will need to put the knotted end in the center hole .
#Text=If it is too small , you can make it bigger but be careful because the knot might slip out of the hole if it is too big .
#Text=Then flip the loom around and organize your threads , one into each slot .
#Text=You can organize them into a certain pattern or just place them around , it does n't matter .
#Text=You may notice you have an empty slot .
#Text=Do n't worry because you will be using this later .
#Text=Point the empty slot toward you and begin moving the threads .
#Text=To move the threads around , count three away from the empty slot going clockwise .
#Text=Move that third thread to the current empty slot and repeat .
#Text=Turn to the new empty slot , count three , move the thread to the slot .
#Text=Tie The End
#Text=Once the bracelet is long enough or it has almost run out of thread , you need to tie it .
#Text=To secure the bracelet , you can either tie one big knot or tie two threads together at a time .
#Text=Split the end into two parts .
#Text=You can braid them to make it cleaner or leave them as they are .
#Text=The best way is to put both ends in the loop on the other side and pull them opposite ways .
#Text=Then thread one side over the top of the loop in the middle .
#Text=Do that with both sides so there is a pretzle looking knot in the middle .
#Text=Bring the two sides up and tie them in a single knot .
#Text=This part is best done with help .
#Text=You are now finished !
#Text=Tips
#Text=The cardboard loom is easiest circular so that the strings are all evenly spread out .
#Text=Using 3 or 4 colors are easiest and is n't too crazy to look at .
#Text=If you braid your bracelet to the very end and tie it off of your wrist , then you can fold it over twice and have a chain looking bracelet .
